Cell growth experiments

In order to find out whether the peptide hydro gels can serve as a scaffold for tissue engineering, its biocompatibility was investigated. Different primary human cells were seeded on top of the hydrogel after its gelation in tissue culture medium (DMEM without serum) in 6-well, 24-well or 96-well culture plates, see the culture conditions below. During the next 2-4 days no change of medium was necessary, but eventually fresh media was added to the wells. The cells were analyzed for viability.

Primary human renal proximal tubule cells (HPTCs) and primary human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) were obtained from ScienCell Research Laboratories (Carlsbad, CA, USA). HPTCs were cultivated in basal epithelial cell medium supplemented with 2% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and 1% epithelial cell growth supplement (all components obtained from ScienCell Research Laboratories). The culture medium for HUVECs was endothelial cell medium containing 5% FBS and 1% endothelial cell growth supplement (ScienCell Research Laboratories). All cell culture media used were supplemented with 1% penicillin/streptomycin solution (ScienCell Research Laboratories), and all cells were cultivated at 37°C in a 5% C02 atmosphere. The seeding density of the cells was about 5 x 104 cells /cm2. However since HUVECs are bigger than HPTCs the cell number would be slightly lower than one for HPTC cells (~ 4.5 x lO4 cells /cm2). Both cell types had a confhiency of about 80% in the wells after seeding.
Crosslinked hydrogels
Material & Methods - Peptides

All peptides were synthesised at American Peptide Company (CA, USA) using SPPS and purified to >95% (HPLC). Amino acid content (AA%) analysis was performed and the net weight (gross weight x AA%) was used for calculations.

Kinetics of disulfide formation
For air oxidation, LKLeC was dissolved in MilliQ water by vigorous vortexing for five minutes and dispensed into 20 μΐ, aliquots. At appropriate time points, 180 μΐ, of DTNB (Sigma, Singapore) working solution (4 mg/mL in 0.1M phosphate buffer pH 7.0) was mixed with the peptide solution for 15 minutes. Absorbance at 412 nm was then measured (InfmiteM200, Tecan, Switzerland). Using a calibration curve generated with L-cysteine (Sigma) as standard (R2=0.999), the background-subtracted value was normalised to the reading at 0 hour to give the % of thiol remaining. For H202-assissted oxidation, LK^C was dissolved in water (HPLC grade, J.T. Baker, NJ, USA) containing 0.06% H202 (Merck, Sinagpore) and dispensed into aliquots. At appropriate time points, the aliquots were analysed using an Aquity® UPLC (Waters, USA) fitted with a single-quadrupole MS. Using a calibration curve generated with pure LKgC as standard (R 0.999), the area under the peak corresponding to LK^C monomer was normalised to that at 0 hour to give the % of thiol remaining.
Gel casting

Peptide was dissolved'in 200 of water +/- H202 and filled into custom-made hollow ring casts (diameter ~1 cm). The ring ends were sealed with parafilm to minimise evaporation and the cast was kept at 25°C for 22 hours before further manipulations.

Rheology: The rheological properties of casted gels were measured with an ARES-G2 (TA Instruments, USA) using the oscillation method. Frequency-sweep studies were performed with co=0- 100 rad/s at strain, γ=0.1%. The gel stiffness was represented by plotting G' against co. Amplitude-sweep studies were performed beforehand at 1 Hz with γ=0-100%. The LVE limit of the gel was defined as the value of γ when G' first dropped below 90% of the average initial value.
Rheology

The rheological properties of casted gels were measured with an ARES-G2 (TA Instruments, USA) using the oscillation method. Frequency-sweep studies were performed with co=0-100 rad/s at strain, γ=0.1%. The gel stiffness was represented by plotting G' against co. Amplitude- sweep studies were performed beforehand at 1 Hz with γ=0-100%. The LVE limit of the gel was defined as the value of γ when G' first dropped below 90% of the average initial value.
FESEM

Freeze-dried gels were deposited onto carbon tapes, sputtered with platinum and observed under a JSM-7400F electron microscope (Jeol, Tokyo, Japan).
3D cell culture

LKeC +/- CRGD gels were casted directly into 8-chamber Lab-Tek® wells (Nunc, NY, USA) and purified as reported in the SI. 0.5 mL of cell suspension in regular completed DMEM (Invitrogen, Singapore) was either seeded onto the gel or directly into the well (2D control) and incubated for four days. 0.5 μΐ. of calcein-AM (Invitrogen) was then added to the media to identify live cells and images were captured using a confocal microscope (LSM5 DUO, Carl Zeiss, Germany). Beforehand, calcein-AM was verified to stain only live cells as etha- nol- and H202-treated cells excluded the dye. All images, except for the 2D controls, were presented as mergers of several z-stacks. To further verify the 3D distribution of cells, the gel was embedded vertically in Jung Tissue Freezing Medium (Leica Instruments GmbH, Germany) and 20 μιη cross-sectional slices were obtained with a cryostat (CM3050 S, Leica). Sections were mounted with coverslips and imaged as above.
Quantification of cell-spread area

Confocal images after calcein staining were processed using ImageJ (NIH, USA) to obtain the average cell-spread area under various culture conditions. For cells in 3D gel culture, images used for quantification were mergers of several z-stacks to capture the maximum cell-spread area. In all cases, at least three independent experiments with at least two locations selected from each culture were used for averaging.
MTT viability assay

After four days of 3D gel culture, cells were separated from the substrate by trypsination and centrifugation and re-seeded into 48-well plates (Nunc) overnight for attachment. MTT (Sigma) dissolved in PBS was then added to the media for four hours, before the formazan crystals were dissolved using DMSO (Sigma). Absorbance was read at 560 nm, subtracted with the 680 nm reference and normalised to the appropriate control to give an indication of relative cell viability.
Statistical analysis
ANOVA testing (OriginLab Corporation, MA, USA) was performed on sample means with p<0.05 being denoted by * and accepted to be statistically significant.

Results
LK6C peptides can be casted into 3-dimensional shapes

LK6C peptides can be easily casted into 3-dimensional gels using the appropriate moulds (see Figure 18). In this experiment, a mould in the shape of a ring was used and LK^C gels were casted using water or completed growth medium. Dextran particles, employed here as a model cargo, could also be encapsulated within the gel matrix.
HbCyassisted formation of disulfide crosslinks

The kinetics of disulfide formation under air oxidation is inefficient (Figure 19). The addition of H202 speeds up disulfide formation (Figure 20). LC-MS confirms the formation of disul- fide-crosslinked dimers in the presence of H202 (Figure 21). The data further suggests that the addition of HRP has no significant effect on the kinetics of disulfide formation (Figure 19). The rate of disulfide formation can also be accelerated by increasing the amount of H202 used (Figure 22).
Oxidation strategy

Two different methods were devised for the H202-assissted crosslinking: 1) The cast-and- soak method, where the gel is first being casted overnight before being soaked in an oxidative solution. 2) The in situ oxidation method where the aqueous solution used to dissolve the peptide powder already contains the oxidative agent (Figure 23).
Oxidation increases the long-term stability of LKgC in water

LK6 or LK6C gels were first casted and then soaked in water for various durations. After 24 hours of water soak, the non-crosslinkable LK6 gels were completely degraded while the non- oxidised h¥^ gels were severely degraded (Figure 24). In stark contrast, LK6C gels oxidised for 2 hours using the cast-and-soak method and LK^C gels oxidised in situ remained intact after 96 hours of water soak. These observations are also supported by rheological measurements (Figure 28). Therefore, the strategy of disulfide crosslinking has increased the resistance of the gel to degradation and has made it possible to use the gel at a lower concentration compared to previous formulations. This, in turn, will translate into significant cost savings.

Gel oxidised using the cast-and-soak method is uniformly oxidised
LK6C gels were casted overnight and then soaked in H202 solution for 2 hours (see scheme in Figure 25). Then the surfaces (circumference + top + bottom layers) were separated from the core and it was shown that the amount of H202 and disulfide/thiol ratio of both the layers were comparable (Figures 25 and 26). This suggests that oxidation is not restricted to the surfaces of the gel and that the diffusion of H202 is rapid in this experimental set-up. However, if the gel is casted into a 48-well plate and the H202 solution is merely applied over the top of the gel (as per later experiments, see scheme in Figure 31), the diffusion rate of H202 will be reduced as only the top surface is accessible to the solution in this configuration.
Effects of oxidation on G' and elasticity of the fiel

The rheological properties of various L C gels were next quantified. As a measure of stiffness, the elastic modulus, G' was plotted against angular frequency, ω after the gel was subjected to 2-24 hours of cast-and-soak oxidation with 0.06% H202, or 24 hours of in situ oxidation with 0.03-0.1% H202 (Figure 27A). Compared to non-oxidised gels, the stiffness was either maintained or increased following different oxidation regimes. Interestingly, the stiffness achieved after 24 hours of cast-and-soak differed from that after in situ oxidation with 0.06% H202. This could be due to the different availability of H202 and sequence of oxidation. More specifically, in cast-and-soak, the gel has access to a sink of H202 and crosslinking happens only after self-assembly of peptide fibers; while during in situ oxidation, H202 is limited to the gel volume and crosslinking occurs concurrently with self-assembly. The linear viscoelastic (LVE) limit (elasticity) of the gel, however, increased 2.4-3.8 fold following oxidation (Figure 27B). This is presumably attributed to the introduction of additional chemical bonds. Other strategies to modulate the stiffness and elasticity of LK6C gels include varying . its concentration (Figure 29A/B) or doping LIQC with LK6 (Figure 29C/D). This also allows the tuning of the amount of thiol groups available in the gel.
Fibrous microstructures of gels
Field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM) revealed that the fibrous microstructures of LK6C gels were maintained after various oxidation regimes (Figure 30).
Η?0? and residual acid readily removed

Using a configuration closer to cell culture experiments, gels were casted overnight in 48-well plates and water was applied over the gels to purify it before the introduction of cells. The majority of H202 and residual acid can be removed be simply changing the water regularly
- -
(Figure 31). Growth medium can be used instead of water to ensure that the gel is essentially free of ¾02 and adjusted to a pH amenable for cell culture.
Gradual and tunable release kinetics

As a model system, dextran particles were encapsulated within the gel and their release profile monitored. No burst release was observed in both cases and release rate was suppressed in the oxidized sample, presumably due to the increased stability in water (Figure 32).
Functionalization of the hydrogel

The gel was next functionalized with a bioactive signal. CRGD (0-1 mg/mL) was simply mixed with LKeC (fixed at 10 mg/mL, i.e., CRGD ligand density 0-9.1 gross weight %) in the presence of H202 and ring-casted overnight. UPLC-MS confirmed the formation of LK6C- CRGD conjugate and the disappearance of free CRGD (Figure 33). The mild and simple reaction conditions are to be noted. A person skilled in the art will also recognize the versatility of this peptide platform as well as the fact that future conjugations need not be limited to RGD. The gels were next purified by a dialysis-inspired method whereby water was layered on top and changed regularly. Doing so, >96% of unreacted H202 was removed after 4 hrs and >99% after 7 hrs (Figure 31 A). Similarly, >85% of residual acid from SPPS was removed after 8 hrs (Figure 31 B).
Biocompatibility and use for cell culture

To test for biocompatibility, HepG2 cells were either seeded directly into wells (2D control) or onto purified LK6C gels conjugated with different concentrations of RGD. After four days, calcein staining revealed that cells were viable in all experiments (Figure 34 A/B). This was repeated with primary rabbit fibroblasts (Figure 35), 3T3 murine fibroblasts (Figure 38) and NIH-3T3 murine fibroblasts (data not shown), confirming the biocompatibility of the gels. With regular media changes, cells remained viable for at least 3 weeks (Figure 38). Images obtained from the gel cultures were presented as mergers of several z-stacks. While that may already suggest a 3D distribution, the inventors wanted to verify that they were not artifacts due to, e.g., the meniscus on gel surfaces or the gel being casted in a non-horizontal position. The gels were therefore embedded vertically and cross-sectional slices were obtained for depth profiling. From Figure 34B, calcein-stained cells Were observed to infiltrate the gel, resulting in multi-layered growth and validating their 3D spatial distribution.
As visually suggested in Figure 34A, HepG2 cells appeared to have proliferated faster within gels with RGD compared to the ones without. This was supported by data from the MTT assay (Figure 34C). Being an anchorage-dependent cell line, the better adhesion to RGD- conjugated gels presumably provided the cells with a more ideal growth environment. Higher magnification images (Figure 36) were subsequently taken and the average cell-spread area of HepG2 cells was quantified. Interestingly, 3D gel culture had insignificant effects (p>0.05) on the average cell-spread area of HepG2 cells compared to those in regular 2D culture (Figure 34D). The amount of RGD ligand present also did not significantly (p>0.05) impact the cell spreading area of HepG2 cells. The trend was different, though, in the case of primary rabbit fibroblasts (Figure 35B) and NIH-3T3 murine fibroblasts (data not shown), both of which spreaded more in 2D culture. Cells are known to respond to mechanical properties such as stiffness and elasticity of their microenvironment and these observations are consistent with an earlier report that hydrogel-encapsulated murine fibroblasts maintained rounder morphologies. However, while a transition from 2D to 3D culture caused the fibroblasts to spread differently, the amount of RGD ligand present had insignificant effects (p>0.05). Compared to before CRGD attachment, the gel was as stiff (Figure 37A) but less elastic (Figure 37B) after conjugation.
Non-allergenicity and non-toxicity

Experiments conducted by the CRO Toxikon further showed that LKgC was non-allergenic and non-toxic. More particularly, LK^C caused no sensitization on the skins of guinea pigs in the direct contact ligman maximization test during a GLP study conducted by Toxikon according to the ISO 10993-10 guidelines. Also, LK6C exhibited no significant toxicity in the direct contact V79 colony assay in another GLP study performed by Toxikon.
Use in wound treatment

A first round of wound healing experiments with mice was conducted. In this model, the epidermis and dermis of mice we removed to simulate injury (Figure 39). The following groups were analyzed: a) No treatment control (i.e., simply bandage up the wound)
b) Application of LK6C-CRGD gel

c) Application of LK6C-CRGD gel with 3T3 murine fibroblasts cultured in 3D
Here, the fibroblasts (the major population of the dermis) act as a therapeutic/bioactive agent. The hypothesis is that the 3T3 cells secrete factors that encourage the growth of keratinocytes, which make up the epidermis. This should further aid healing as compared to the gel-only treatment (group b).

After 2 weeks, the extent of vascularisation of the wound (a prerequisite feature of recovery) was indeed most significant in group c, followed by group b and then group a (Figure 40). Subsequent histology also showed the regeneration of a significant dermal layer in group c mice. In comparison, group b mice had less regenerated dermis, and group a mice had the least extent of dermal regeneration.
Summary

Cysteine-mediated disulfide-crosslinked ultrasmall peptide hydrogel were analyzed. Cross- linking was driven by H202 and produced only water as a by-product. Moreover, H202 helped to maintain the sterility of the gel and can be virtually removed before the introduction of cells. Oxidation increased both the elasticity of the gel and its ability to keep its shape after being soaked in water. Due to the cysteine residue, bioactive signals can be conjugated to the peptide fibers using facile chemistry and gels can be easily purified. Gels formed were shown to support the true 3D distribution of cells and influence their growth and spreading characteristics. Furthermore, their applicability in wound treatment was demonstrated.
Screening of a small library of cvsteine-containing peptides

We surveyed a family of cysteine-containing peptides for their gel forming abilities and mechanical properties (Figure 41). Ac-IVKC, in particular, caught our attention for its outstanding stiffness after crosslinking and more data on this candidate has been provided in the following paragraphs.
Tuning the crosslinking density and stiffness of Ac-IVKC with H^O? concentration

The crosslinking density of Ac-IVKC was modulated by varying the concentration of H202 (0-0.2%). The amount of monomelic (retention time~2.40 mins) and dimeric (~2.67 mins) species were then quantified with ultra-performance liquid chromatography (UPLC) after incubation in the various H202 concentration for 24 hours at room temp (Figure 42). As can
be seen, crosslinking degree increased from 0% to 100 % with increasing concentration of ¾<¾.

The corresponding effect of the crosslinking density of Ac-IV C on gel stiffness (G') was examined using oscillatory rheometry. A graph of stiffness (G') vs angular frequency (ω) was plotted (Figure 43). As can be seen, as crosslinking degree increased, the stiffness of the gel increased. A G' value of nearly 1 MPa was achieved, which is one of the highest so far for our class of peptide hydrogel.

Pictures of the Ac-IVKC gel were taken as the concentration of H202 (0-0.2%) was varied (Figure 44). As can be seen, all gels were transparent and became noticeably stiffer as the crosslinking degree increased from 0% to 100 % with increasing concentration of H202.
Thin layer casting of Ac-IVKC

We attempted to cast a thin layer of Ac-IVKC in between 2 glass plates with sides sealed for moisture retention (Figure 45A-B). Two glass plates were held together with clips separated by a spacer with a thickness of 750 μη . A solution of the gel was then injected in between the glass plates and allowed to gel overnight. To retrieve the gel, the glass plates were separated. Gel was easily retrieved from glass plate, was transparent (Figure 45C-D) and easily handled (Figure 45E).

claim.claim-text: 1. A hydrogel comprising a plurality of amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids capable of self-assembling into three-dimensional macromolecular nanofibrous networks, which entrap water and form said hydrogel, the amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids having the general formula:
■¾-(X)n-(Y)m-AAthiol-Z q,
wherein
Z is an N-terminal protecting group,
X is, at each occurrence, independently selected from an aliphatic amino acid,
Y is, at each occurrence, independently selected from a hydrophilic amino acid,
AAthioi is an amino acid comprising a thiol group,
Z' is a C-terminal protecting group,
n is an integer selected from 2 to 6, preferably 2 to 5,
m is selected from 0, 1 and 2, preferably 0 and 1 ,
and p and q are independently selected from 0 and 1 , wherein, preferably, p is 1 , wherein at least a portion of said plurality of amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids is chemically cross-linked.
2. The hydrogel of claim 1 , wherein said amino acid comprising a thiol group is selected from cysteine and homocysteine.

3. The hydrogel according to claim 1 or 2, wherein said at least a portion of said plurality of amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids is chemically cross-linked via sulfhydryl-to- sulfhydryl cross-linking, via sulfhydryl-to-hydroxyl cross-linking, via sulfhydryl-to-aldehyde cross-linking, via sulfhydryl-to-amine cross-linking, via peptidoglycans or via photo-induced cross-linking, preferably via sulfhydryl-to-sulfhydryl cross-linking.

4. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said N-terminal protecting group has the general formula -C(0)-R, wherein R is selected from the group consisting of H, unsubstituted or substituted alkyls, and unsubstituted or substituted aryls.
5. The hydrogel of claim 4, wherein said N-terminal protecting group is an acetyl group.

6. The hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 3, wherein said N-terminal protecting group is a peptidomimetic molecule, including natural and synthetic amino acid derivatives, wherein the N-terminus of said peptidomimetic molecule may be modified with a functional group selected from the group consisting of carboxylic acid, amide, alcohol, aldehyde, amine, imine, nitrile, an urea analog, thiol, phosphate, carbonate, sulfate, nitrate, maleimide, vinyl sulfone, azide, alkyne, alkene, carbohydrate, imide, peroxide, ester, thioester, aryl, ketone, sulphite, nitrite, phosphonate and silane.
7. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said C-terminal protecting group is an amide group.

8. The hydrogel of claim 7, wherein the C-terminus of said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids has the formula -CONHR or -CONRR', with R and R' being selected from the group consisting of H, unsubstituted or substituted alkyls, and unsubstituted or substituted aryls.
9. The hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 6, wherein said C-terminal protecting group is an ester group.

10. The hydrogel of claim 9, wherein the C-terminus of said amphiphilic peptide and/or peptoid has the formula -C02R , with R being selected from the group consisting of H, unsubstituted or substituted alkyls, and unsubstituted or substituted aryls.

11. The hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 6, wherein said C-terminal protecting group is a peptidomimetic molecule, including natural and synthetic amino acid derivatives, wherein the C-terminus of said peptidomimetic molecule may be modified with a functional group selected from the group consisting of carboxylic acid, amide, alcohol, aldehyde, amine, imine, nitrile, an urea analog, thiol, phosphate, carbonate, sulfate, nitrate, maleimide, vinyl sulfone, azide, alkyne, alkene, carbohydrate, imide, peroxide, ester, thioester, aryl, ketone, sulphite, nitrite, phosphonate and silane.

12. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein, for a given amphiphilic peptide and/or peptoid, said aliphatic amino acid, said hydrophilic amino acid and said amino acid comprising a thiol group are either D-amino acids or L-amino acids.

13. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said hydrophilic amino acid has a polar group which is independently selected from a hydroxyl, an ether, a carboxyl, an imido, an amido, an ester, an amino, a guanidino, a thio, a thioether, a seleno, and a telluro group.

14. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said hydrophilic amino acid is selected from the group consisting of aspartic acid, asparagine, glutamic acid, glutamine, 5- N-ethyl-glutamine (theanine), citrulline, thio-citrulline, cysteine, homocysteine, methionine, ethionine, selenomethionine, telluromethionine, threonine, allo-threonine, serine, homoserine, arginine, homoarginine, ornithine (Orn), 2,4-diaminobutyric acid (Dab), 2,3- diaminopropionic acid (Dap), lysine and N(6)-carboxy-methyllysine and histidine.

15. The hydrogel of claim 14, wherein said hydrophilic amino acid is selected from the group consisting of aspartic acid, asparagine, glutamic acid, glutamine, serine, threonine, cysteine, methionine, lysine, ornithine (Orn), 2,4-diaminobutyric acid (Dab), 2,3- diaminopropionic acid (Dap) and histidine.

16. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said aliphatic amino acid is selected from the group consisting of isoleucine, norleucine, leucine, valine, alanine, glycine, homoallylglycine and homopropargylglycine.

17. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein all or a portion of the aliphatic amino acids of the amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids are arranged in an order of decreasing amino acid size in the direction from N- to C-terminus of the amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids, wherein the size of the aliphatic amino acids is defined as I = L > V > A > G.
18. The hydrogel of claim 17, wherein said aliphatic amino acids arranged in an order of decreasing amino acid size have a sequence which is a repetitive or non-repetitive sequence.

19. The hydrogel of claim 17 or 18, wherein said aliphatic amino acids arranged in an order of decreasing amino acid size have a sequence selected from LIVAG, ILVAG, LIVAA, LAVAG, IV AG, LIVA, LIVG, IVA and IV, wherein, optionally, there is an A preceding such sequence at the N-terminus.

20. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids undergo a conformational change during self-assembly, preferably a conformational change from a random coil conformation to a helical intermediate structure to a final beta conformation.

21. The hydrogel of claim 20, wherein the conformational change is dependent on the concentration of the amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids, dependent on the ionic environment, pH dependent and/or temperature dependent.
22. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids are the same or different.

23. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein (X)n-(Y)m-AAthi0i is selected from the group consisting of LIVAGKC (SEQ ID NO: 43), LIVAGSC (SEQ ID NO: 44), LIVAGDC (SEQ ID NO: 45), ILVAGKC (SEQ ID NO: 46), ILVAGDC (SEQ ID NO: 47), LIVAGC (SEQ ID NO: 48), AIVAGC (SEQ ID NO: 49), ILVAGC (SEQ ID NO: 50), IVKC (SEQ ID NO: 51), IVDC (SEQ ID NO: 52) and IVSC (SEQ ID NO: 53).

24. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein the hydrogel is stable in aqueous solution at ambient temperature for a period of at least 7 days, preferably at least 2 to 4 weeks, more preferably at least 1 to 6 months.

25. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein at least 5%, preferably at least 10%, more preferably at least 15%, more preferably at least 20%, more preferably at least 25%, more preferably at least 30%, more preferably at least 35%, more preferably at least 40%, more preferably at least 45%, even more preferably at least 50% of said plurality of amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids are chemically cross-linked.
26. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein the hydrogel is characterized by a storage modulus G' to loss modulus G" ratio that is greater than 2.

27. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein the hydrogel is characterized by a storage modulus G' from 100 Pa to 1 ,000,000 Pa, preferably 500 Pa to 1 ,000,000
Pa, more preferably 1000 Pa to 1,000,000 Pa, at a frequency in the range of from 0.02 Hz to 16 Hz.

28. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein the hydrogel has an elasticity defined as % strain at linear viscoelasticity (LVE) limit above 0.01% strain, preferably above 0.5% strain, more preferably above 1% strain, more preferably above 2% strain.
29. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, further comprising a non-peptidic polymer.

30. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein the hydrogel further comprises at least one of a microorganism, a cell, a virus particle, a peptide, a peptoid, a protein, a nucleic acid, an oligosaccharide, a polysaccharide, a vitamin, an inorganic molecule, a nano- or microparticle, a synthetic polymer, a small organic molecule, a cosmetic agent or a pharmaceutically active compound.

31. The hydrogel of claim 30, wherein said at least one of a microorganism, a cell, a virus particle, a peptide, a peptoid, a protein, a nucleic acid, an oligosaccharide, a polysaccharide, a vitamin, an inorganic molecule, a nano- or microparticle, a synthetic polymer, a small organic molecule, a cosmetic agent or a pharmaceutically active compound is entrapped by said three- dimensional macromolecular nanofibrous networks.

32. The hydrogel of claim 30 or 31 , wherein said at least one of a microorganism, a cell, a virus particle, a peptide, a peptoid, a protein, a nucleic acid, an oligosaccharide, a polysaccharide, a vitamin, an inorganic molecule, a nano- or microparticle, a synthetic polymer, a small organic molecule, a cosmetic agent or a pharmaceutically active compound is coupled to said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids, preferably via a disulfide bridge.

33. The hydrogel of claim 30 or 31, wherein said at least one of a microorganism, a cell, a virus particle, a peptide, a peptoid, a protein, a nucleic acid, an oligosaccharide, a polysaccharide, a vitamin, an inorganic molecule, a nano- or microparticle, a synthetic polymer, a small organic molecule, a cosmetic agent or a pharmaceutically active compound is coupled to said non-peptidic polymer.

34. The hydrogel of any one of claims 30 to 33, wherein said pharmaceutically active compound is selected from the group consisting of haemostatic agents, antibiotics, antimicrobial agents, anti-fungal agents, anti-inflammatory agents, analgesics, anti-coagulants, antibodies, antigens, growth factors and cytokines.
35. The hydrogel of any one of claims 30 to 33, wherein said nano- or microparticle is a metal nano- or microparticle, preferably a gold nano- or microparticle.

36. The hydrogel of any one of claims 30 to 33, wherein said peptide comprises a signal sequence, wherein, preferably, said peptide is coupled to said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids via a disulfide bridge.
37. The hydrogel of claim 36, wherein said signal sequence comprises an adhesion or growth signal, such' as an integrin binding sequence.
38. The hydrogel of any one of the foregoing claims, wherein said hydrogel is provided in an injectable form and gels in situ.

39. A method of preparing a hydrogel, preferably a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38, the method comprising the step of dissolving amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids as defined in any one of claims 1 to 23 in an aqueous solution,
wherein said aqueous solution comprises an oxidizing agent or
wherein said method further comprises the step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to a solution of an oxidizing agent.

40. The method of claim 39, wherein said oxidizing agent is H202, wherein, preferably, H202 is used at a concentration from 0.02 to 0.3 % (w/w), preferably "from 0.05 to 0.25 % (w/w), more preferably "from 0.05 to 0.2 % (w/w).

41. The method of claim 39 or 40, wherein said amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids are dissolved at a concentration from 0.01 g/ml to 50 mg/ml, preferably at a concentration from 1 mg/ml to 25 mg/ml, more preferably at a concentration from 1 mg/ml to 15 mg/ml, even more preferably at a concentration from 5 mg/ml to 12 mg/ml.

42. The method of any one of claims 39 to 41, wherein the dissolved amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids in aqueous solution are further exposed to a temperature in the range of from 20°C to 90°C, preferably 20°C to 70 C, more preferably 20°C to 40°C.

43. The method of claim 42, wherein the dissolved amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids in aqueous solution are exposed to said temperature for at least 1 hour, preferably at least 2 hours, more preferably at least 4 hours, more preferably at least 6 hours, more preferably at least 8 hours, more preferably at least 10 hours, more preferably at least 12 hours, even more preferably at least 24 hours.

44. The method of any one of claims 39 to 43, further comprising the step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to an aqueous solution not comprising said oxidizing agent, wherein, if said method comprises the step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to a solution of said oxidizing agent, said step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to an aqueous solution not comprising said oxidizing agent is performed after said step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to a solution of said oxidizing agent.
45. The method of claim 44, wherein said step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to an aqueous solution not comprising said oxidizing agent is repeated at least once.

46. The method of claim 44 or 45, wherein said step of exposing the ready-made hydrogel to an aqueous solution not comprising said oxidizing agent occurs for at least 1 hour, preferably at least 2 hours, more preferably at least 4 hours, even more preferably at least 6 hours.

47. The method of any one of claims 44 to 46, wherein said step of exposing the ready- made hydrogel to an aqueous solution not comprising said oxidizing agent occurs at a temperature in the range of from 30°C to 45 °C, preferably 35 °C to 40°C.
48. The method of any one of claims 39 to 47, further comprising at least one of the steps of:

- adding at least one of a microorganism, a cell, a virus particle, a peptide, a peptoid, a protein, a nucleic acid, an oligosaccharide, a polysaccharide, a vitamin, an inorganic molecule, a nano- or microparticle, a synthetic polymer, a small organic molecule, a cosmetic agent or a pharmaceutically active compound;
- adding at least one non-peptidic polymer;
- adding at least one gelation enhancer;
- adding at least one buffer, preferably at least one physiologically acceptable buffer.
49. The method of claim 48, wherein said gelation enhancer is a salt or a solution of a salt.
50. A hydrogel prepared by the method of any one of claims 39 to 49.
51. Use of a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 as a cell culture substrate, pref- erably a cell culture substrate for 3-D cell culture.

52. Use of a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 as a device for drug or gene delivery, preferably for sustained or controlled release drug delivery, or as a wound dressing or as an implant or as an injectable agent that gels in situ.
53. A cell culture substrate, preferably a cell culture substrate for 3-D cell culture, comprising a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50.
54. A device for drug or gene delivery, preferably sustained or controlled release drug delivery, comprising a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50.
55. An implant or injectable agent or wound dressing comprising a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50.
56. A pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition comprising a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50.

57. The pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition of claim 56, wherein the pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition is provided in the form of a topical gel or cream, a spray, a powder, or a sheet, patch or membrane.
58. The pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition of claim 56, wherein the pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition is provided in the form of an injectable solution.
59. The pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition of any one of claims 56 to 58, further comprising a pharmaceutically active compound.
60. The pharmaceutical or cosmetic composition of any one of claims 56 to 59, further comprising a pharmaceutically acceptable carrier.
61. A hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 for use in regenerative medicine or for use in tissue engineering and tissue regeneration, e.g. regeneration of adipose and cartilage tissue.
62. A hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 for use in the treatment of wounds.
63. A hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 for use in the treatment of degenerative diseases of the skeletal system, e.g. degenerative disc disease, or urinary incontinence.
64. A hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50 for cosmetic use.
65. An electronic device comprising a hydrogel of any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50.
66. The electronic device of claim 65 being selected from a fuel cell, a solar cell, an electronic cell or a biosensing device.
67. A method of tissue regeneration or tissue replacement comprising the steps: a) providing a hydrogel as defined in any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50;
b) exposing said hydrogel to cells which are to form regenerated tissue;
c) allowing said cells to grow on or in said hydrogel.
68. The method of claim 67, which is performed in vitro or in vivo or ex vivo.
69. The method of claim 68, which is performed in vivo, wherein, in step a), said hydrogel is provided at a place in the body of a patient where tissue regeneration or tissue replacement is intended.

70. The method of claim 69, wherein said tissue is selected from the group comprising skin tissue, nucleus pulposus in the intervertebral disc, cartilage tissue, synovial fluid and submucosal connective tissue in the bladder neck.

71. The method of claim 69 or 70, wherein said step a) is performed by inj ecting said hydrogel or a solution of amphiphilic peptides and/or peptoids as defined in any one of claims 1 to 23 at a place in the body of a patient where tissue regeneration or tissue replacement is intended.
72. The method of claim 71 , wherein said step a) further comprises the co-injection of a gelation enhancer, preferably of a solution of a salt, and/or the co-injection of an oxidizing agent.

73. The method of claim 68, which is performed ex vivo, wherein, in step a) or b), cells from a patient or from a donor are mixed with said hydrogel, and the resulting mixture is provided at a place in the body of a patient where tissue regeneration or tissue replacement is intended.
74. The method of any one of claims 67 to 73, wherein said hydrogel comprises one or more bioactive therapeutics that stimulate regenerative processes and/or modulate the immune response.

75. A thin layer obtained from a hydrogel as defined in any one of claims 1 to 38 and 50, preferably by glass plate casting, or casting with stain-less steel, inert metals, non-reactive polymeric material.
